name: X-Caboquinho
curiosity: The X-Caboquinho is a traditional dish from Manaus, known as one of the most iconic snacks in Amazonian culture. It combines tucumã, an Amazonian fruit, with grilled cheese and bread.
suggestions: Serve with cassava flour on the side.

steps.description: Cut the French rolls in half, but do not separate the halves completely.
Spread butter on the inner halves of each roll.
Lightly heat the rolls in a frying pan to brown the butter.
Cut the tucumã into thin, even strips.
Place the tucumã strips in a bowl and set aside.
Cut the coalho cheese into slices and grill until golden on both sides.
Place the grilled cheese on a plate and set aside.

preparationMethods.stage: Preparation of the Bananas and Assembly

steps.description: Peel the bananas and cut them into thin slices.
In a frying pan, heat the banana slices until they are lightly golden.
Assemble the sandwiches by adding the ingredients prepared by the other chefs: tucumã strips, grilled cheese, and banana slices.
Place the assembled sandwiches back in the hot frying pan and cook for 2 minutes on each side, making sure all the ingredients are well integrated.

name: Japanese Ramen
curiosity: Curiosity: Although popular in Japan, ramen originates from China and was adapted by the Japanese, who created their own regional variations and unique techniques for the dish.
suggestions: You can replace the pork with shredded chicken, shiitake mushrooms, or tofu, if preferred;
If you don't have nori, you can use wakame seaweed flakes or even shredded dried seaweed.

preparationMethods.stage: Preparing the Toppings and Heating the Bowls

steps.description: Start by preparing the toppings as you prefer (pork loin and boiled eggs) and set them aside.
Heat the bowls where the ramen will be served.
Boil the water and then add the pork and chicken broth, soy sauce, salt, and ginger.
Let it all boil and then simmer on low heat.
For the noodles, boil the water and cook them until al dente.
Drain the noodles and then divide them into four portions.

For assembling, place the noodles first, then the broth, and finish with your preferred toppings. The recommended toppings are half a boiled egg, two pieces of cooked pork loin, bamboo shoots to taste, a slice of kamaboko, and another slice of nori for each serving.
Serve hot immediately.

name: Pizza
curiosity: Curiosidade: Embora popular no Japão, o lámen é originário da China e foi adaptado pelos japoneses, que criaram suas próprias variações regionais e técnicas únicas para o prato.

ingredients.name: de caldo de carne de porco

suggestions: Você pode substituir o porco, por frango desfiado, cogumelos shiitake ou tofu, se preferir;
Se não tiver nori, pode usar flocos de alga marinha (wakame) ou até algas secas desfiadas.

steps.description: Corte os pães ao meio, mas sem separar completamente as metades.
Passe manteiga nas duas metades internas de cada pão.
Aqueça levemente os pães em uma frigideira para dourar a manteiga.
Corte o tucumã em tiras finas e uniformes.
Coloque as tiras de tucumã em uma tigela e reserve.
Corte o queijo coalho em fatias e grelhe até dourar dos dois lados.
Coloque o queijo grelhado em um prato e reserve.
Descasque as bananas e corte-as em fatias finas.
Em uma frigideira, aqueça as fatias de banana até ficarem levemente douradas.
Monte os pães, adicionando os ingredientes preparados pelos outros chefs: tiras de tucumã, queijo grelhado e fatias de banana.
Leve os pães montados à frigideira quente para aquecer por 2 minutos de cada lado, garantindo que todos os ingredientes fiquem bem integrados.

name: Tuna Mayo Onigiri
curiosity: Curiosity: Onigiri was one of the samurais' foods because, due to its practicality and lightness, it was wrapped in bamboo leaves and carried by samurais on their journeys.

ingredients.name: Nori (seaweed) cut into strips to taste

suggestions: You can replace the tuna with shredded chicken or salmon, whichever you prefer;
If you don't have nori, you can use wakame seaweed flakes or even shredded dried seaweed.

steps.description: Start by washing the rice with clean water. Place the rice in a bowl and add water. Mix the rice quickly with your hand until the water becomes cloudy.
Place the rice in a pot with double its volume of cold water. Cover and bring to a boil.
Once the water boils, stir the rice off the heat, reduce to low, and cook for 15 minutes, covered.
Remove from heat and let it rest for 10 minutes so the rice can steam and expand.

preparationMethods.stage: Cutting Nori Sheet and Mixing Ingredients

steps.description: Cut the nori sheet into 6 wide strips.
Mix the tuna, mayonnaise, and mustard in a bowl.
Wet your hands and then generously cover your palms with salt to prevent the rice from sticking to your hands.
Take a little rice in your hand and create a depression in the center. Place some filling in the middle.
Add rice to your hand to seal the rice ball. Press with your other hand until it forms a triangular shape.
Wrap your onigiri in the nori sheet.
Place them on a plate in an organized manner.

name: Three-Color Dango
curiosity: Curiosity: With shades of pink, green, and white, these dangos are highly appreciated during hanami (cherry blossom viewing), adding a festive and joyful atmosphere to any occasion.

ingredients.name: of sugar (optional, for a sweet touch on the dango)

suggestions: If you cannot find glutinous rice flour (mochi-ko), you can use rice starch or tapioca flour;
Instead of food coloring, you can use beet juice or natural strawberry juice to get the pink tone;
If you can't find matcha, you can use regular green tea powder, spinach juice, or green strawberries.

steps.description: In a large bowl, mix the glutinous rice flour (mochi-ko) with salt and sugar (if using).
Gradually add warm water while mixing until the dough is consistent but still slightly sticky. If needed, add a little more water or rice flour to adjust the consistency.
Divide the dough into three portions: one for the white dumplings, one for the green dumplings, and one for the pink dumplings.
Remove from heat and let the dough rest for 10 minutes to allow the rice to puff up in its steam.
Add the red food coloring (or beet juice) to one portion and mix well until the dough achieves the desired color.
In the second portion, add matcha powder and mix until the color is uniform. Leave the third portion white without adding any coloring.
Shape the three portions of dough into small balls of approximately 2 cm in diameter (making 12 dumplings in total).
In a large pot, bring water to a boil.
When the water is boiling, carefully add the dango balls. Cook for about 5 to 8 minutes, or until they rise to the surface.
Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them in a container with cold water to cool down a bit.
Once the dango have cooled down a bit, place them on bamboo skewers, alternating the colors (e.g., 1 white, 1 green, 1 pink).
If desired, prepare the sauce by mixing soy sauce, sugar, and mirin in a pot. Heat until the sugar completely dissolves. Serve the sauce on the side so each person can dip their dango as they like.
